awd_titl_txt: MRI Collaborative: Development of ESPRIT - Emerging systems' performance and energy evaluation instruments and testbench
awd_abstract_narration:
Future computing nodes will most likely rely on heterogeneous processing and memory systems as well as networking technologies. Identifying the most suitable computing system for a given application requires the cumbersome task of evaluating the application's performance on as many alternatives as possible. This project develops ESPRIT (Emerging Systems PeRformance and Energy Evaluation Instrument and Testbench), a computing system capable of evaluating the most suitable system for specific classes of applications. If applications can be classified into groups based on their similarities along a wide range of performance characteristics, it may be possible to determine the system best suited for a specific class of applications. This work will help large-scale computing systems be configured for more efficient operation and lower energy use.

The ESPRIT project consist of state of the art computing nodes; system, memory, and power and energy simulators; benchmarks from different applications; a suite of measuring instruments; models for investigating application behaviors; statistical clustering and other machine learning techniques.The merit of this project resides in the development of instruments to evaluate applications along a number of performance characteristics of behaviors and classifying them into clusters in order to identify the most suitable design for energy efficiencies by varying capacities as well as technology scales. ESPRIT could be used to investigate new design choices, or tune applications for specific designs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our research reveals that system configuration and parameter setting play a critical role in the behavior of computing systems and there exist significant coupling effects between different types of system resources such as processors and memory. Understanding and modeling their interactions are essential to achieving accurate performance prediction and optimizing the performance of different classes of applications running in different computing systems.

Based on these findings, we developed a profiling-based cross-layer coupled design framework, which determines the best parameter setting for each layer in the entire computing system to optimize computing workflow performance. To tackle the large parameter space, we reduced the number of experiments needed for profiling with two approaches: i) identify a subset of critical parameters with the most significant influence through machine learning-based feature selection; and ii) minimize the search process within the value range of each critical parameter using stochastic approximation. Particularly, we designed a streaming application optimization algorithm, which dynamically tunes system configurations to optimize real-time streaming application performance with negligible overhead and proved convergence.

Our research also resulted in a class of models for workflow-structured application clustering and classification, a performance-influence model using random forest for performance prediction, and an information composition mechanism to aggregate distributed datasets using a composition operator of specific complexity, as required by many big data applications.
